overview: This subject investigates issues of social and emotional development across all life periods of the life-span: childhood, adolescence, young adulthood, middle adulthood, and late adulthood. Students taking this subject will learn about major developmental tasks and issues for each life period, including: identity development, gender and sexuality development, moral development, family and peer relationships, and education.
ilo: critically evaluate competing (and complimentary) theories of social and emotional development across the lifespan
generic_skills: creating and responding to peer-reviews and feedback
applying theory to practice in everyday life

Inherent requirements (core participatio.content: Further details on how to seek academic adjustments can be found on the Student Equity and Disability Support website:http://services.unimelb.edu.au/student-equity/home

assessment.brief: 1 written reflective piece addressing 3 questions (500 words per question)
5 lecture revision quizzes (1 released each fortnight), Note, each quiz is worth 2% of the final grade. Students can complete the quizzes any time up to week 12.

assessment.hurdle: Failure to meet the attendance hurdle will result in additional assessment pieces being set before students can be considered to have satisfactorily completed the subject.

assessment.brief: Participation in 2 x peer review activities (week 4 and week 8). Each peer review activity includes: (i) Submitting 1 draft answer to one of the 3 final questions (500 words) for peer review; and (ii) Completing an anonymous review of 2 other students' drafts.
assessment.hurdle: Meeting the peer review hurdle requires submission of 2 draft answers and completing 4 reviews. Failure to meet the peer-review hurdle will result in additional assessment pieces being set before students can be considered to have satisfactorily completed the subject.
